message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of crusty, greasy patches on the skin of the scalp that appeared 1 week ago is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly affects infants. The other options do not match the specific presentation described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medi... The presentation of greasy patches on the skin of the scalp suggests seborrheic dermatitis. Atopic dermatitis would present with dry, itchy, and inflamed skin. Impetigo presents with honey-colored crusting lesions and chickenpox presents with vesicles or blisters on the skin. The patient’s behavior and vital signs are normal, ruling out more serious conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of greasy, scaly patches on the scalp is most consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly occurs in infants. Atopic dermatitis usually presents as itchy, red, and dry patches, while impetigo presents as small, blister-like lesions with honey-colored crusts. Chickenpox presents with a vesicular rash throughout the body and can cause fever and other systemic symptoms. The patient's normal growth and development and lack of systemic symptoms make chickenpox less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of crusty, greasy patches on the scalp with yellow, scaly patches and evidence of inflammation is characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis. Atopic dermatitis usually presents with dry, itchy skin and can affect other areas of the body. Impetigo presents with honey-colored crusts and chickenpox presents with vesicles on an erythematous base. The patient's behavior and vital signs are normal, which supports the diagnosis of seborrheic dermatitis being a benign condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly presents as greasy, yellow, scaly patches on the scalp in infants. The other options would have different symptoms and skin findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly occurs in infants and causes scaly patches on the scalp. Atopic dermatitis usually occurs on other parts of the body and is associated with itching. Impetigo is a bacterial infection that causes crusting and oozing of skin lesions, and chickenpox causes a widespread rash with fluid-filled blisters. These diagnoses are less likely based on the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesion fits seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly affects infants and is characterized by greasy, scaly patches on the scalp with inflammation. Atopic dermatitis usually presents with itching and a family or personal history of allergies or asthma. Impetigo presents as honey-colored crusts on an erythematous base and chickenpox presents with vesicular eruptions. The patient's normal development and stable vital signs also support a diagnosis of seborrheic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly occurs in infants on the scalp, eyebrows, and face. Atopic dermatitis would typically present with dry, itchy patches on the skin and is more common in older children. Impetigo presents as crusted or oozing lesions, and chickenpox presents with a vesicular rash.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The crusty, greasy patches on the skin of the scalp with evidence of inflammation are classic signs of seborrheic dermatitis seen in infants. Atopic dermatitis does not typically have greasy patches and impetigo presents as honey-colored crusting lesions. Chickenpox typically presents with a generalized skin rash and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are typical of seborrheic dermatitis, which commonly affects infants. Atopic dermatitis often presents with red, itchy, and dry skin lesions, while impetigo presents with honey-colored crusting lesions and chickenpox presents with a widespread blistering rash.
